Award.AwardTitle: Unraveling the role of iron-sulfur clusters in RNA polymerase

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit:
The objective of this project is to elucidate the functional role of the iron-sulfur (Fe-S) clusters, recently discovered in subunits of archeal and eukaryal RNA polymerase (RNAP). RNAP is a multi-subunit enzyme that copies DNA to produce RNA, in a fundamental process called transcription that occurs in all living cells and is the first step in gene expression. The core subunits of RNAP are conserved in all three domains of life (Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya). In structure and complexity, archaeal RNAPs resemble those of eukarya, rather than the less complex RNAPs of bacteria, even though both archaea and bacteria are single-celled organisms lacking nuclei. Furthermore, Fe-S clusters are only found in the RNAPs of archaeal and eukaryal species and are absent from all bacterial RNAPs. Specifically, Fe-S clusters are found in the RpoD subunits of the RNAPs of some archaea and in the homologous subunits of some eukaryal RNAPs. RpoD is not directly involved in RNA synthesis but serves to promote the assembly of RNAP and regulate its activity.

These findings raise intriguing questions that will be addressed in the project: What is the purpose of the Fe-S clusters in RNAP? Why do only certain species contain them? How do the Fe-S clusters function to regulate the assembly or activity of RNAP in response to environmental signals?

These questions will be addressed using the methane-producing archaeon Methanosarcina acetivorans (Ma) as a model organism. MaRpoD is predicted to bind two Fe-S clusters. Because M. acetivorans only grows in the absence of oxygen, it is likely the clusters serve to regulate the assembly or activity of RNAP in response to oxygen or oxidative stress. The specific aims of the project include: 1) determine the number and type of Fe-S clusters in MaRpoD and their redox-properties, including the sensitivity to oxygen. 2) Develop strains of M. acetivorans capable of expressing mutant rpoD alleles to test the affects on MaRNAP activity and Ma strain viability of the presence of defective MaRpoD that are unable to bind Fe-S clusters. These studies are expected to reveal whether the Fe-S clusters are critical for the formation and activity of MaRNAP, and thereby to stimulate studies of the function and evolution of RNAPs in other Archaeal or Eukaryal species.

Broader impacts:
The project will contribute to the education and training of students in the biochemistry, physiology, and genetics of strictly anaerobic microorganisms and Archaea, a field that is underrepresented at all education levels. The project will support two graduate students and provide research opportunities for undergraduates. Undergraduates from diverse backgrounds will be recruited from Historically Black Colleges and Universities, Hispanic-serving institutions, and Tribal Colleges in conjunction with the University of Arkansas? George Washington Carver research program. Each summer the project will provide support for one of these students to conduct research in the laboratory of the PI. The PI will continue to provide summer research opportunities for Arkansas High School students by serving as a mentor with the Upward Bound Summer Program in Math and Science at the University of Arkansas. Students will be provided the opportunity to present their findings at the Northwest Arkansas Regional Science and Engineering fair. An advanced Prokaryotic Biology laboratory course for undergraduates will be enhanced, integrating new findings, techniques, and concepts from the research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All cells store information in genes within DNA and access this information in response to changes in the external and internal cellular environments. The information within genes is first accessed by the activity of a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RNAP) which transcribes the DNA into RNA, which in turn can be used to produce proteins.  RNAP is comprised of several individual proteins that must first assemble to form functional RNAP. Since synthesis of RNA by RNAP requires an input of energy, regulating the assembly of RNAP may control the levels of functional RNAP in response to available energy and/or a cell’s ability to conserve energy. Iron is an essential element to cells because it is a cofactor required by many enzymes, including those containing iron-sulfur clusters. Iron-sulfur cluster proteins catalyze oxidation/reduction reactions in cells during energy conserving processes, including respiration and photosynthesis. Thus, iron limitation or damage of iron-sulfur clusters by oxygen significantly impacts the ability of a cell to conserve energy. Genomic evidence predicts that RNAP from several species of archaea (e.g. methanogens) and eukaryotes (e.g. plants) contain an iron-sulfur cluster(s) in the RpoD/Rpb3 subunit, which is the starting point for the assembly of RNAP. Iron-sulfur cluster(s) are absent from RNAP in bacteria. Iron-sulfur clusters in RNAP may correlate the assembly and activity of RNAP with energy available from processes dependent on iron-sulfur cluster enzymes. This mechanism of regulation is likely especially important for cells that grow in the absence of oxygen (i.e. anaerobes), since anaerobes typically contain a higher amount of iron-sulfur cluster proteins.

 

We used biochemical and genetic approaches to demonstrate that RpoD of RNAP from Methanosarcina acetivorans, an anaerobic archaeon, contains two iron-sulfur clusters. The RpoD iron-sulfur clusters are damaged by oxygen, and the absence of the clusters impacts the assembly and activity of RNAP in M. acetivorans. These results provide fundamental knowledge of how the assembly and activity of RNAP is controlled using iron-sulfur clusters within cells in response to environmental signals.  Since anaerobic archaea are an ancient group of organisms, likely present before the rise of atmospheric oxygen more than 2.5 billion years ago, these results provide insight into how early life evolved to use iron-sulfur clusters to correlate energy conservation with information processing. We also developed new methods to assess the tolerance of M. acetivorans to oxidants (e.g. oxygen) and validated these methods.

 

The project was able to broaden the impact of the research funding by providing hands-on scientific training for one research associate (Hispanic female), four graduate students, nine undergraduate students, and three high school students. The project provided avenues for participation by individuals from groups underrepresented in scientific research. Specifically, several female (one African American) and Hispanic students were involved in the project.  Most students are not familiar with the biology of archaea, compared to bacteria and eukaryotes, and do not realize the importance of archaea to our biosphere. Since the project used an archaeal species as a model, students were exposed to new concepts and information pertaining to these lesser-known organisms, which will lead to more young people becoming interested in scientific research involving archaea. In addition to gaining hands-on experience with archaea and RNAP, students also learned general experimental design, data analysis, and scientific writing. Data generated by two of the undergraduate students resulted in co-authorship on research articles published in a peer-reviewed journals.
